title: 111_hr1842
content: The "Expanding Entrepreneurship Act of 2009" may be cited as the official title of the Act. This Act aims to promote and support entrepreneurship. Section 4 of the Small Business Act is amended to include a plan for using the Small Business Administration's entrepreneurial development programs to create jobs during fiscal years 2010 and 2011. The plan will draw on existing programs like Small Business Development Centers, Women's Business Centers, SCORE, Veterans Business Centers, Native American Outreach, and others. Each Administration region will have a strategy to create or retain jobs. The Administrator will establish performance measures and criteria for job creation, retention, and retraining goals in entrepreneurial development programs. A rule will be implemented for consistent data collection covering all programs to evaluate success in job creation and performance. The Administrator will establish performance measures and criteria for job creation, retention, and retraining goals in entrepreneurial development programs. Additionally, the Administrator will submit an annual report to Congress on opportunities to foster coordination, limit duplication, and improve program delivery for Federal entrepreneurial development programs. A database of entrepreneurial development service providers will be established and made available through the Administration's website, searchable by industry, geography, and service required. The Administrator will designate community specialists in each district office to work with local entrepreneurial development service providers and develop benchmarks for their performance. A web-based portal will be created to provide information on entrepreneurial development programs, integrating them under one platform after a public comment period. The Small Business Administration will integrate various entrepreneurial development programs under one web portal, increase consumer-oriented content, and establish industry-specific web content. The Small Business Administration will integrate entrepreneurial development programs under one web portal, provide industry-specific web content, and offer resources such as financing, training, and counseling. Pilot programs cannot conflict with existing entrepreneurial development programs. The Small Business Administration will integrate entrepreneurial development programs under one web portal, providing industry-specific web content, resources like financing, training, and counseling. Passed the House of Representatives on November 18, 2009.
